title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
The belief that Covid escaped from a Chinese laboratory is no longer being dismissed as a Trump provocation. As Demetri Sevastopulo writes from Washington, the order by US president Joe Biden for US intelligence to intensify efforts to determine the origins of Covid-19 has given fresh life to the theory that the virus may have leaked from the Wuhan Institute of Virology.

Biden said that US intelligence had “coalesced around two scenarios” — that the virus had either emerged naturally or was the result of a lab accident. It was the first time that Biden had given credence to the possibility that the virus had leaked from a lab — a notion widely slammed as a conspiracy theory when Donald Trump first made the claim.

Today's FT View is that understanding the origins of this pandemic is vital to preventing another, but that determining the truth is not about apportioning blame. It would be far better for China finally to allow unfettered access to international investigators — unlikely as that may be — to hunt for the answer.

Coronavirus digest

  • The OECD has said the global economy will return to pre-pandemic levels by 2022, giving governments leeway to scale back emergency support and focus on investing.

  • Covid cases continue to rise in Argentina, with tough new measures risking further damage to the economy.

  • Sweden will tomorrow become the last Nordic country to begin easing coronavirus restrictions.

  • Vietnam said it had detected a new variant that combines features of the variants first identified in India and the UK.

  • Australia's Qantas Airways is touting cheaper airfares and the prospect of unlimited flights to customers who have taken Covid-19 jabs, as the country's businesses turn to creative means to counter vaccine hesitancy.

In the news

Thrill-seeking traders send ‘meme stocks' soaring as crypto tumbles A new breed of day traders chasing thrills in the intense ups and downs of markets is asserting its dominance again, sending shares in popular stocks surging while cryptocurrency prices wilt. Professional analysts say the rerun shows that the amateur fascination with markets can outlast the social curbs brought in last year to control the coronavirus pandemic.

China allows couples to have three children The policy shift comes shortly after reports of the slowest population growth rate in decades but ignored calls to scrap the historic family policies entirely in the face of a looming demographic crisis. The announcement of the three-child policy was met with a swift backlash on social media.

Texas Democrats block proposed law that would restrict voting rights The Democrats blocked a final vote on a law that would tighten voting restrictions in the US's second most-populous state, after staging a late-night walkout from the legislature following hours of tense debate. The move denied the Republican majority a chance to pass the bill ahead of a midnight deadline that marked the end of the legislative session.

Nestlé document says majority of its food portfolio is unhealthy The world's largest food company, Nestlé, has acknowledged in an internal document that more than 60 per cent of its mainstream food and drinks products do not meet a “recognised definition of health” and that some categories and products “will never be ‘healthy' no matter how much we renovate”.

Russia releases $500m loan to Belarus Moscow has agreed to release $500m in credit to Minsk and look to increase the number of flights between the two countries as the Kremlin doubled down on its support for Alexander Lukashenko after his forced landing of a passenger flight that has sparked western condemnation.

  • More Belarus news: critics are decrying Joe Biden's plan to hold a summit with Russia's president Vladimir Putin despite Moscow's backing of Lukashenko. After the forced landing, Washington announced it would reimpose sanctions on nine state-owned Belarusian companies.

Israel opposition's deal to unseat Benjamin Netanyahu Opposition parties have banded together to try to form a minority government that could unseat the country's longest-serving prime minister and head off the country's fifth election in two years. Talks on forming a new administration were abandoned earlier this month after the outbreak of 11 days of conflict between Israel and Hamas, the Palestinian militant group.

GOP blocks probe of deadly assault on US Capitol Republicans in the US Senate have thwarted efforts to form a bipartisan commission to investigate the January 6 assault on the US Capitol, in a vote that was the latest evidence of Donald Trump's enduring influence in his party.

Russian group behind SolarWinds spy campaign targets USAID Hackers who breached several US government agencies last year have hijacked an email system used by the development agency to target more than 150 government agencies, human rights groups and NGOs worldwide, said Microsoft.

The day ahead

100th anniversary of the Tulsa Race Massacre The Greenwood neighbourhood in Oklahoma was once one of the wealthiest black communities in the US. But on May 31 1921, a white mob stormed the neighbourhood, killing at least 38 people as they laid waste to “Black Wall Street”. (WSJ)

Observation of Memorial Day Today is a day of remembrance for those who have died in service to the US. It was initially known as Decoration Day, and originated after the Civil War. Memorial Day — the last Monday in May — became an official federal holiday in 1971.

What else we're reading

Investors weigh whether to cash in on stock profits as summer kicks off Equities investors are sitting on solid returns since the start of the year, leading them to ask one of the oldest questions in finance: should they take their profits before the summer holidays kick into full gear? US stocks are up about 11 per cent since the start of 2021, while those across European bourses have risen about 12 per cent, according to MSCI indices that track both markets in dollar terms. Equities in the Asia-Pacific region have climbed a more modest 4 per cent. But is taking some chips off the table before the summer revs up a successful strategy? Chris Flood investigates.

Europe's bold plan on emissions For a number of EU governments and green activists, Brussels' carbon-pricing instrument risks throwing the continent's poorest inhabitants further into energy poverty by making them shoulder the burden of the rush towards net zero. Separately, a sharp rise in the cost of polluting in Europe risks undermining airlines' efforts to repair their balance sheets post-pandemic. It comes as the European Central Bank is facing pressure to deal with environmental threats.

The 2020s: a decisive economic decade for the UK The decade will determine whether we have a chance of averting irreversible damage to the climate. But for the UK, this comes together with other big challenges. Its response will also determine what happens to the wellbeing of its people, writes Martin Wolf.

Hong Kong's dilemma: ‘Either you shut up or you leave' Thousands in the Chinese territory have applied for UK visas after the country pledged a path to citizenship for up to 3m Hong Kongers who hold or are eligible for a British National (Overseas) passport. The UK offered the right to stay in response to China's new national security law.

Will the workers ever come back? A curious Covid-19 development: rich countries are facing labour shortages even though millions are still out of work. As economists debate the causes and consequences, the rest of us can only marvel at how abruptly the labour landscape has changed, writes Pilita Clark. The pandemic is a chance to disrupt office norms. Andrew Hill asks: what might business leaders do to keep their organisations up with evolving rules and guidance? How has the world of work changed for you? Let us know at firstft@ft.com.

Five lessons from 25 years of corporate wealth creation A McKinsey Global Institute white paper offers five takeaways for policymakers and corporate leaders to inform the debate over the role of corporations in society. Among them: the rewards of a superstar economy must be shared more equally, writes Rana Foroohar.

Video of the day

Why every dogecoin has its day FT markets editor Katie Martin and markets news editor Adam Samson explain the most speculative asset class and how a token designed as a joke about a picture of a dog online is now worth billions of dollars.
